AGAINST JOHNNIES!

By J. MURRAY KEMPTON
It'll be Bing Crosby's brother, Bob,
or Jimmy Dorsey's brother, Tommy,
at the Second Cotillion next February 19th, authoritative sources reported this week. At present, the report runs, the Board has narrowed
its field down to the "all-star" aggregations of Crooner Crosby and trombonist Dorsey, who toiled together
two years ago in the old Dorsey
Brothers combination.
Which puts those earnest souls to
whom swing is an all-embracing passion in rather a hot spot. If the
Board chooses Crosby it will rend
their artistic natures by depriving
them of an opportunity to hear Mr.
Dorsey and his trombone along with
Bud Freeman and his tenor sax, Jeff
Dixon and his clarinet, Max Kaminsky
and his trumpet, and Dave Tough and
his drums. And that, according to
one half-tearful swingtaster, speaking from the card-tables of Levering
Hall, is quite a deprivation.
But suppose, as this reporter suggested in giant ignorance, we pass
up the younger Crosby and take Dorsey instead. His informant looked
up tragically from a careful study
of the hand on which he has just bid
four.
he said, "there's the rub."
Did the reporter not realize that
the Crosby Orchestra is one of the
most significant representatives of
the modern movement? Had he never
heard Matty Mattlock's clarinet and
Eddie Miller's tenor sax? And that
rhythm section headed by drummer
Ray Beauduc, and the superlative
piano of the immortal—the incomparable Joe Sullivan.

ford, chairman of the June Week Committee. Seniors voted last week to
show their preference in the type of
Spring events which are to climax
their undergraduate careers at Hopkins.
"As things look now we'll probably engage one nationally famous
orchestra—I don t know which one—
and several local bands for the smaller
dances," Bradford. "No conclusion
has been reached as to the music
preferred by the Seniors, because
almost each ballot, that specified a
preference, was in favor of a different
orchestra."
Those Seniors who have not already
voted in the June Week balloting will
have a chance to do so in a couple of
weeks when aditional ballots will be
sent out, according to Roy Galloway,
president of the Senior Class.
"No support, no June Week," was
the cryptic statement issued by Galloway.
The financial failure of the 1936
June Week, proceeds of which were
to have been donated to the sustaining fund of the University, is reputed
to be the cause of the added caution
of this year's Senior Class.

By BENJAMIN ROOT
With the rapid approach of February 22, the day marking the culmination of the twenty-fifth anniversary
celebration in the Engineering School,
the various departments of the School
are all busy completing preparations
for the exhibits which will be shown
by them during the celebration. The
Civil Engineering Department is
practically finished with its work, and
has an array of exhibits calculated to
be interesting and instructive for all.
The exhibit is under the general direction of J. Trueman Thompson, professor of Civil Engineering.
In Latrobe 120, the main hall of the
Civil Engineering building, the exhibits will particularly emphasize
transportation. In the center of the
room there will be a miniature railroad, complete in most details. Operating trains of different sorts will be
controlled by a central switching system, while roundhouses, water tanks,
and the like, will complete the realistic picture.
Around walls of the hall will be
found a chronological panorama of
the development of American transportation from 1830 to 1937. Featured
in this exhibit are a model of the
Peter Cooper engine, a series of airplanes models including a model of
the China Clipper, and a group of
dioramas which show the development of the American highway. The
latter includes a diorama showing the
National Pike from Baltimore to Ohio
In stage-coach days. The latest shows
a model of the Bath Street Viaduct in
Baltimore.

On the stage at the far end of the
room will be found four large dioramas, which, sa3rs Professor Thompson "are the most beautiful and interesting things in that line that I have
seen." One of these is of the Triborough Bridge and is a night scene,
showing the moonlight up the water
and the passing rows of cars. Another diorama shows the possibilities
of slum clearance by comparing in intimate detail a section in the slums
and a newly built section having the
low-rent apartment houses. The third
and fourth dioramas both have to do
with flood control. One shows the
havoc wrought by a flood, while the
other shows a large dam in the distance and a rebuilt community.
Various types of drivers' tests will
be given in Latrobe 214. Any visitor
who so desires may take these tests,
which include tests of steering ability,
ability to judge distances, quickness
in jamming on brakes in an emergency, and the effect the glare of
headlights has upon the person's ability to see while driving at night. Moreover, the motion picture "Saving Seconds" will be shown.
The visitor to the show will be able
to enter the Highway Engineering
and Hydraulics laboratories and see
there the routine work being carried
on.
Some of the research work in the
Department will be shown to visitors.
A desk type motion picture machine
will be in operation and will show
some of the 40,000 lineal feet of film

before young people can derive
from it the happiness it should yield,"
Dr. S. Ralph Harlow, Massachusetts
cleric and educator, said before the
Supper Club Tuesday evening.
"Our students can learn about the
biology of the frog, or the anatomy of
a white rat, but they must depend on
outside sources to get information
about this field," he continued.
Dr. Harlow, who is professor of Religion and Social Ethics at Smith College, feels that courses ought to be
given in every college on marriage and
the family.
Discussing fundamental points leading to marriage, the speaker said,
"The corner stone of real and enduring
happiness in marriage is the ability to
like each other, plus the emotional
love for one another." By liking Dr.
Harlow, means having mutual interests and such as music and literary
pursuits. He illustrated his talk with
several cases in which the husband
and wife had had exactly opposite
likes and dislikes, and where it came
to the point that neither of them enjoyed doing anything mutually.

Dr. Harlow also felt that if women
did the choosing, instead of men,
there would be fewer unhappy marriages. "Man is a creature of short
range emotions, and he thinks almost
entirely in terms of the present.

By J. C. HANDELSMAN
The Hopkins wandering Blue Jays
return to roost once again in Homewood cage as they meet the St. John's
quintet tomorrow night in their second game of the Maryland Inter-collegiate Basketball League. The Malloneemen have just returned from an
invasion of the north, where they encountrede Army and the Swarthmore
dribblers.
The game tomorrow night is
awaited with expectancy and the student bodies of both schools, in order
that once more te iraditiona rivalship between Johnnies and Jays may
be reshmed. Feeling rdns high and
specolation is rampant, with both
teams ready to do or die.
Blue Team Dangerous
High hopes are held for the Hopkins .hardwoodmen, as they have
shown themselves, when in top form,
to be an invincible combine. Fast and
acurate on the offense, and dangerous
defense players, they have proven
their metle.
The Hopkins will probable use the
same starting line-up as they have
been all season. Shorty Cross will
batle the tap and jump for rebounds,
with Captain Herb Seigel and Norm
Melvin carrying the fight to the Johnnies from their forward berths. Ace
Zheutlin an Carl Rasin, Stellar back
court men, can be counted on to turn
in their usual sprakling performances.
The smooth passing and dribbling
Annapolis five starts its third contest
tomorrow night, still thirsting for its
first drink from the cup of victory.
They dropped their initial contest to
Elon College, Losing again last Wednesday night to Gettysburg by seven
points. The Johnnie,s have been seriously handicapped to date by the absence of their star guard, L. Koogle,
conspicuous by his absence since the
beginning of the season.
The St. John's Dribblers have an
outfit that can click dangerously at
times. However, they will be at a
disadvantage against the Hopkins
giants, for the Johnines as a group
are small. Their forwards are fast,
tricky, and evasive. Ross, on the left,
is a phenomenal shot when on the
run. Lambros is also a high scorer.
F. Delisio, at guard, is a. man with
plenty of experience. A hard player,
he fills his berth capably. Filling
Koogle's shoes is G. Shawn, reserve

Cosmopolitan Club
Hears Wm. S. Pike
William S. Pike VVill Give Lecture
On California Tomorrow;
Will Be Illustrated
Despite the proximity of the midyear examinations, the Cosmopolitan Club has resolved to hold a regular meeting this Saturday at 8.30 P.M.
in the Levering Hall Parlor.
The speaker for the evening will be
William S. Pike, principal of Friends
School, whose subject, "California—
the Land of Vivid and Striking Contrast," will be illustrated by motion
pictures in color.
Dan de Lima, president of the Cosmopolitan Club, in discussing the
speaker, said, "Under the presidency
of Vidkun Yarl two years ago, the
club had the pleasure of having Mr.
Pike address us and I am sure he will
succeed again in educating and entertaining us in his pleasing manner.
Everyone is welcome."

"We feel that a very important
principle has been violated. Hershner
Cross, Student Council President excused the

undemocratic action by

the

maintaining that the budget had to
be made very quickly and there was
no time for a student referendum.
Investigation on our part seems to indicate, however, that a few days neccessary for a referendum could have
been spared very easily before the
budget was established. The great
haste was unnecessary. The maintenance of democratic procedure on vital
issues is much more fundamental than
imagined slight inconveniences.
"Finally, as a positive action to
make sure that the student body will
be taken into account in the future,
we suggest that an amendment be incorporated into the Constitution of
the Student Council, making necessary a general student referendum
on any proposal of compulsory assessments before passage by the Student
Council.
Sincerely yours,
Maurice Shils
For the Executive Committee
American Student Union."

A Good Plan But —

The new plan for class dues should
prove to be the solution to the problem
of stabilizing class financial affairs—
if the proper supervision is made.
We are in favor of class functions.
Most of the students strongly support such projects inwardly but do not
always contribute to the treasury to
make such affairs financially solvent.
The few students who object to these
are negligible. By and large, the type
of class project provided for by the
new plan is worthwhile and adds to
the richness and enjoyment of university life.
The plan shows understanding of
the kernounts usually spent, deficits
usually incurred, and in general presents a realistic view of the situation.
However, we feel that the idaitional
fee assessed each student without his
advice or consent and collected by the
University represents a dangerous
tendency. To the charge of the undemocratic proceclurr, the Student
Council claims that it is a duly-elected
body and any disagreement of the
students with Counicl's decision could
bs registered in the selection of new
representatives in the Spring. True,
but why wait so long before the desires of the students are sought and
tested? Besides, are our representatives chosen for the ideas they represent?
This move made by a very small
group of students (S.A.C., Student
Council and signed by Robert Austrian
and James Bradford) shows the importance of these groups.
Certainly, a more definite and wider
seeking of student opinion and suggestions should have been made. Once
before money was collected separately
by the University, then included with
tuition with certain advantages to activities maintainance. This support
was not fully kept up.
Any move concerning student affairs which affects the pocketbooks of
the students should certainly ultimately and directly be decided by
them.
While the class situation was being discussed why wasn't some plan
put forth for the present Junior and
Senior Class? These are real problems

Reprinted from the Washington Elm., Saturday, January 9,

By Phil Skipp
Last night found the Shoremen successfully invading Baltimore where
the locals tangled with Johns Hopin the opening Maryland Intercollegiate League game for both teams. It
was a successful inauguration of a
relentless campaign which is expected
to enable our red shirted squad to
retain the gonfalon, symbolic of the
league championship. And tonight
Coach Kibler's proteges have high
hopes of continuing their winning
streak when they match ability with
Western Maryland. The Green Terrors have always proved a great drawing card, so it is safe to assume that
the large Chestertown Armory will
be overflowing with fans eager to see
Zebrowski and Co. extend their winning streak that began last winter
and was supplemented by a few successful preholiday skirmishes.

of the new year will be Ernest J.
Simmon's life of Pushkin, announced

January it will publish the first volume, with the title, "Factors Determining Human Behavior."

On Saturday, January 10, the Debating Team of The Johns Hopkins
University took the negative side, and
that of Manhattan College of New
York took the affirmative side in a
debate on the resolution; "Resolved
--that Congress be empowered to fix
minimum wages and maximum hours
for industry."
Held in the Commons Room of the
Alumni Memorial Hall, the winner of
the debate was not officially judged.
Each team, however, in conclusion
stated that its members were just as
sincerely convinced of the logic and
justification of their stand as they
had been when the debate started.
Regret was expressed that there could
be no decision rendered.
Both teams have stated the particulars in which they feel that their
opponents failed to refute their arguments or put forth reasoning which
would entitle it to the decision.
John P. Moore, president of the
Manhatta.n team, said on the conclusion of the debate:
"The Manhattan Debating team
has derived great satisfaction from
the auspicious inception of forensic
relations with Johns Hopkins University. We sincerely hope that these relaticms will be continued in the future.
"The stand taken by the Negative
in this morning's debate, while logical and well-executed, was lacking in
several respects. We do not believe
the Negative team can logically maintain the status quo, and at the same
time profess sympathy with the exploited laboring classes. We feel that
It is incumbent upon the Negative
not only to disprove the Affirmative
plan, but to propose some alternative
which can better secure the desired
elimination of present abuses.
"In our constructive case, four possible alternatives were considered.
The last of these, action by the Federal Government has, we believe,
been proven most desirable and practical.
"The economic and ethical implications of this question cannot, as the
gentlemen of the Negative maintained, be divorced. The dignity of
labor, and the mass' right to a living
wage must be recognized by any economic system which is to work for
the promotion of the common good."

Dutch Lentz, St. Johns coach has
every confidence in his boys. Last year
the Johnnies split with the Blue Jays
in two contests. This year they are
out to better last year's record, while
the Jays will make every effort to
heighten their league standing.
As we go to press, a teletype flash
has just come in. On the Hopkins
campus, feeling is running wild. A
venturesome freshman has just prepared to stake his all, so great is his
confidence in the Big Blue dribblers.
Gathering all his financial resources
in one lump sum, he runs to the station, makes his way to Annapolis and
the St. John's campus. "All my money
on Hopkins!" he yells. "Any takers?"
The St. John's men are aghast. Finally he gets a taker. "Here," gasps the
pride and joy of the Jays, "Put my
clime on the Blue Team!"

to Down Beat, is about all any patron of the arts can ask in the way of

stand-off. Whichever of the two gentlemen in question graces the Alcazar

not.

The Johns Hopkins Big Blue Quint
bowed in defeat before a salvo from
the future generals at West Point
Wednesday afternoon. The Army defense held the Malloneemen to five
baskets, which, coupled with seven
tallies on fouls gave the Blues their
final seventen, as compared with the
West Pointers' 50. At the half Army
led 23 to 8.
Ace Zheutlin was high scorer for the
Blue Dribblers with six points, having scored one of the field goals. Carl
Rasin followed with three points, also
scoring from mid-court. The Blue
men put up a tremendous scrap
throughout. They were so effectively
bottled in, that it was only through
sheer fight that they were able to
score as they did. Every man on the
team displayed a fine brand of basketball.
The Cadets showed a much more
polished and spectacular type of basketball. Their cutting and passing was
very smooth, their shooting deadly.
Brinker, scoring 14 points, was outstanding for the cadets.
After the game, the Hopkins quintet
embarked for Pennsylvania to meet
Swarthmore.

The Jay wrestlers dropped their
second successive meet Wednesday
night when they lost to Getysburg
College by the score of 23-9 on the
floor of the Hopkins gym.
Bobby Vernon started the meet off
well for Hopkins when he won the
first match against Manges of Gettysburg Wednesday night in the 118 lb.
class. He surprised the onlookers by
starting on the bottom of the pile and
following through on top to gain a
time advantage of 7 minutes and 48
seconds. In the 126 lb. class, Besseker,
the Pennsylvanian, overcame Linthicum and threw him with a half-nelson
and arm lock after a scrappy battle.
Sammy Rosenstein came back for
the home team when he tok the laurels away from Kabayaski in the 135
lb. class. Kabayaski proved to be a
very springy Hawaiian and gave the
Hopkins lad plenty of trouble. However, the perserverance and experience of Rosenstein led to a time advantage of 4 minutes and 40 seconds. Saturday, Jan. 16, 8:15 P.M.

By J. MURRAY KEMPTON
It'll be Bing Crosby's brother, Bob,
or Jimmy Dorsey's brother, Tommy,
at the Second Cotillion next February 19th, authoritative sources reported this week. At present, the report runs, the Board has narrowed
its field down to the "all-star" aggregations of Crooner Crosby and trombonist Dorsey, who toiled together
two years ago in the old Dorsey
Brothers combination.
Which puts those earnest souls to
whom swing is an all-embracing passion in rather a hot spot. If the
Board chooses Crosby it will rend
their artistic natures by depriving
them of an opportunity to hear Mr.
Dorsey and his trombone along with
Bud Freeman and his tenor sax, Jeff
Dixon and his clarinet, Max Kaminsky
and his trumpet, and Dave Tough and
his drums. And that, according to
one half-tearful swingtaster, speaking from the card-tables of Levering
Hall, is quite a deprivation.
But suppose, as this reporter suggested in giant ignorance, we pass
up the younger Crosby and take Dorsey instead. His informant looked
up tragically from a careful study
of the hand on which he has just bid
four.
he said, "there's the rub."
Did the reporter not realize that
the Crosby Orchestra is one of the
most significant representatives of
the modern movement? Had he never
heard Matty Mattlock's clarinet and
Eddie Miller's tenor sax? And that
rhythm section headed by drummer
Ray Beauduc, and the superlative
piano of the immortal—the incomparable Joe Sullivan.

ford, chairman of the June Week Committee. Seniors voted last week to
show their preference in the type of
Spring events which are to climax
their undergraduate careers at Hopkins.
"As things look now we'll probably engage one nationally famous
orchestra—I don t know which one—
and several local bands for the smaller
dances," Bradford. "No conclusion
has been reached as to the music
preferred by the Seniors, because
almost each ballot, that specified a
preference, was in favor of a different
orchestra."
Those Seniors who have not already
voted in the June Week balloting will
have a chance to do so in a couple of
weeks when aditional ballots will be
sent out, according to Roy Galloway,
president of the Senior Class.
"No support, no June Week," was
the cryptic statement issued by Galloway.
The financial failure of the 1936
June Week, proceeds of which were
to have been donated to the sustaining fund of the University, is reputed
to be the cause of the added caution
of this year's Senior Class.

By BENJAMIN ROOT
With the rapid approach of February 22, the day marking the culmination of the twenty-fifth anniversary
celebration in the Engineering School,
the various departments of the School
are all busy completing preparations
for the exhibits which will be shown
by them during the celebration. The
Civil Engineering Department is
practically finished with its work, and
has an array of exhibits calculated to
be interesting and instructive for all.
The exhibit is under the general direction of J. Trueman Thompson, professor of Civil Engineering.
In Latrobe 120, the main hall of the
Civil Engineering building, the exhibits will particularly emphasize
transportation. In the center of the
room there will be a miniature railroad, complete in most details. Operating trains of different sorts will be
controlled by a central switching system, while roundhouses, water tanks,
and the like, will complete the realistic picture.
Around walls of the hall will be
found a chronological panorama of
the development of American transportation from 1830 to 1937. Featured
in this exhibit are a model of the
Peter Cooper engine, a series of airplanes models including a model of
the China Clipper, and a group of
dioramas which show the development of the American highway. The
latter includes a diorama showing the
National Pike from Baltimore to Ohio
In stage-coach days. The latest shows
a model of the Bath Street Viaduct in
Baltimore.

On the stage at the far end of the
room will be found four large dioramas, which, sa3rs Professor Thompson "are the most beautiful and interesting things in that line that I have
seen." One of these is of the Triborough Bridge and is a night scene,
showing the moonlight up the water
and the passing rows of cars. Another diorama shows the possibilities
of slum clearance by comparing in intimate detail a section in the slums
and a newly built section having the
low-rent apartment houses. The third
and fourth dioramas both have to do
with flood control. One shows the
havoc wrought by a flood, while the
other shows a large dam in the distance and a rebuilt community.
Various types of drivers' tests will
be given in Latrobe 214. Any visitor
who so desires may take these tests,
which include tests of steering ability,
ability to judge distances, quickness
in jamming on brakes in an emergency, and the effect the glare of
headlights has upon the person's ability to see while driving at night. Moreover, the motion picture "Saving Seconds" will be shown.
The visitor to the show will be able
to enter the Highway Engineering
and Hydraulics laboratories and see
there the routine work being carried
on.
Some of the research work in the
Department will be shown to visitors.
A desk type motion picture machine
will be in operation and will show
some of the 40,000 lineal feet of film

before young people can derive
from it the happiness it should yield,"
Dr. S. Ralph Harlow, Massachusetts
cleric and educator, said before the
Supper Club Tuesday evening.
"Our students can learn about the
biology of the frog, or the anatomy of
a white rat, but they must depend on
outside sources to get information
about this field," he continued.
Dr. Harlow, who is professor of Religion and Social Ethics at Smith College, feels that courses ought to be
given in every college on marriage and
the family.
Discussing fundamental points leading to marriage, the speaker said,
"The corner stone of real and enduring
happiness in marriage is the ability to
like each other, plus the emotional
love for one another." By liking Dr.
Harlow, means having mutual interests and such as music and literary
pursuits. He illustrated his talk with
several cases in which the husband
and wife had had exactly opposite
likes and dislikes, and where it came
to the point that neither of them enjoyed doing anything mutually.

Dr. Harlow also felt that if women
did the choosing, instead of men,
there would be fewer unhappy marriages. "Man is a creature of short
range emotions, and he thinks almost
entirely in terms of the present.

Cosmopolitan Club
Hears Wm. S. Pike
William S. Pike VVill Give Lecture
On California Tomorrow;
Will Be Illustrated
Despite the proximity of the midyear examinations, the Cosmopolitan Club has resolved to hold a regular meeting this Saturday at 8.30 P.M.
in the Levering Hall Parlor.
The speaker for the evening will be
William S. Pike, principal of Friends
School, whose subject, "California—
the Land of Vivid and Striking Contrast," will be illustrated by motion
pictures in color.
Dan de Lima, president of the Cosmopolitan Club, in discussing the
speaker, said, "Under the presidency
of Vidkun Yarl two years ago, the
club had the pleasure of having Mr.
Pike address us and I am sure he will
succeed again in educating and entertaining us in his pleasing manner.
Everyone is welcome."

"We feel that a very important
principle has been violated. Hershner
Cross, Student Council President excused the

undemocratic action by

the

maintaining that the budget had to
be made very quickly and there was
no time for a student referendum.
Investigation on our part seems to indicate, however, that a few days neccessary for a referendum could have
been spared very easily before the
budget was established. The great
haste was unnecessary. The maintenance of democratic procedure on vital
issues is much more fundamental than
imagined slight inconveniences.
"Finally, as a positive action to
make sure that the student body will
be taken into account in the future,
we suggest that an amendment be incorporated into the Constitution of
the Student Council, making necessary a general student referendum
on any proposal of compulsory assessments before passage by the Student
Council.

A Good Plan But —

The new plan for class dues should
prove to be the solution to the problem
of stabilizing class financial affairs—
if the proper supervision is made.
We are in favor of class functions.
Most of the students strongly support such projects inwardly but do not
always contribute to the treasury to
make such affairs financially solvent.
The few students who object to these
are negligible. By and large, the type
of class project provided for by the
new plan is worthwhile and adds to
the richness and enjoyment of university life.
The plan shows understanding of
the kernounts usually spent, deficits
usually incurred, and in general presents a realistic view of the situation.
However, we feel that the idaitional
fee assessed each student without his
advice or consent and collected by the
University represents a dangerous
tendency. To the charge of the undemocratic proceclurr, the Student
Council claims that it is a duly-elected
body and any disagreement of the
students with Counicl's decision could
bs registered in the selection of new
representatives in the Spring. True,
but why wait so long before the desires of the students are sought and
tested? Besides, are our representatives chosen for the ideas they represent?
This move made by a very small
group of students (S.A.C., Student
Council and signed by Robert Austrian
and James Bradford) shows the importance of these groups.
Certainly, a more definite and wider
seeking of student opinion and suggestions should have been made. Once
before money was collected separately
by the University, then included with
tuition with certain advantages to activities maintainance. This support
was not fully kept up.
Any move concerning student affairs which affects the pocketbooks of
the students should certainly ultimately and directly be decided by
them.
While the class situation was being discussed why wasn't some plan
put forth for the present Junior and
Senior Class? These are real problems

By Phil Skipp
Last night found the Shoremen successfully invading Baltimore where
the locals tangled with Johns Hopin the opening Maryland Intercollegiate League game for both teams. It
was a successful inauguration of a
relentless campaign which is expected
to enable our red shirted squad to
retain the gonfalon, symbolic of the
league championship. And tonight
Coach Kibler's proteges have high
hopes of continuing their winning
streak when they match ability with
Western Maryland. The Green Terrors have always proved a great drawing card, so it is safe to assume that
the large Chestertown Armory will
be overflowing with fans eager to see
Zebrowski and Co. extend their winning streak that began last winter
and was supplemented by a few successful preholiday skirmishes.

of the new year will be Ernest J.
Simmon's life of Pushkin, announced
for publication by the Harvard University Press on February 10th, the
centenary of Pushkin's death.
Mr.
Simmon's book is based upon firsthand acquaintaince with Pushkin material in the Russian archives and upon several visits to places in Russia
connected with Pushkin's career.

January it will publish the first volume, with the title, "Factors Determining Human Behavior."

On Saturday, January 10, the Debating Team of The Johns Hopkins
University took the negative side, and
that of Manhattan College of New
York took the affirmative side in a
debate on the resolution; "Resolved
--that Congress be empowered to fix
minimum wages and maximum hours
for industry."
Held in the Commons Room of the
Alumni Memorial Hall, the winner of
the debate was not officially judged.
Each team, however, in conclusion
stated that its members were just as
sincerely convinced of the logic and
justification of their stand as they
had been when the debate started.
Regret was expressed that there could
be no decision rendered.
Both teams have stated the particulars in which they feel that their
opponents failed to refute their arguments or put forth reasoning which
would entitle it to the decision.
John P. Moore, president of the
Manhatta.n team, said on the conclusion of the debate:
"The Manhattan Debating team
has derived great satisfaction from
the auspicious inception of forensic
relations with Johns Hopkins University. We sincerely hope that these relaticms will be continued in the future.
"The stand taken by the Negative
in this morning's debate, while logical and well-executed, was lacking in
several respects. We do not believe
the Negative team can logically maintain the status quo, and at the same
time profess sympathy with the exploited laboring classes. We feel that
It is incumbent upon the Negative
not only to disprove the Affirmative
plan, but to propose some alternative
which can better secure the desired
elimination of present abuses.
"In our constructive case, four possible alternatives were considered.
The last of these, action by the Federal Government has, we believe,
been proven most desirable and practical.
"The economic and ethical implications of this question cannot, as the
gentlemen of the Negative maintained, be divorced. The dignity of
labor, and the mass' right to a living
wage must be recognized by any economic system which is to work for
the promotion of the common good."

The Johns Hopkins Big Blue Quint
bowed in defeat before a salvo from
the future generals at West Point
Wednesday afternoon. The Army defense held the Malloneemen to five
baskets, which, coupled with seven
tallies on fouls gave the Blues their
final seventen, as compared with the
West Pointers' 50. At the half Army
led 23 to 8.
Ace Zheutlin was high scorer for the
Blue Dribblers with six points, having scored one of the field goals. Carl
Rasin followed with three points, also
scoring from mid-court. The Blue
men put up a tremendous scrap
throughout. They were so effectively
bottled in, that it was only through
sheer fight that they were able to
score as they did. Every man on the
team displayed a fine brand of basketball.
The Cadets showed a much more
polished and spectacular type of basketball. Their cutting and passing was
very smooth, their shooting deadly.
Brinker, scoring 14 points, was outstanding for the cadets.
After the game, the Hopkins quintet
embarked for Pennsylvania to meet
Swarthmore.

The Jay wrestlers dropped their
second successive meet Wednesday
night when they lost to Getysburg
College by the score of 23-9 on the
floor of the Hopkins gym.
Bobby Vernon started the meet off
well for Hopkins when he won the
first match against Manges of Gettysburg Wednesday night in the 118 lb.
class. He surprised the onlookers by
starting on the bottom of the pile and
following through on top to gain a
time advantage of 7 minutes and 48
seconds. In the 126 lb. class, Besseker,
the Pennsylvanian, overcame Linthicum and threw him with a half-nelson
and arm lock after a scrappy battle.
Sammy Rosenstein came back for
the home team when he tok the laurels away from Kabayaski in the 135
lb. class. Kabayaski proved to be a
very springy Hawaiian and gave the
Hopkins lad plenty of trouble. However, the perserverance and experience of Rosenstein led to a time advantage of 4 minutes and 40 seconds. Saturday, Jan. 16, 8:15 P.M.
